Reject a frame if its residual shift exceeds this many pixels after alignment.
Star detection threshold in œÉ above background. Lower = more stars (faster saturation, more false positives); higher = fewer stars.
Minimum connected-pixel area to keep a detection as a star (px). Helps reject hot pixels/noise.
Caps Astroalign max_control_points (typical 500‚Äì1500). Lower = faster, higher = more robust.
Per-frame alignment timeout for the parallel workers. Default 300s.
Enable GPU/MPS via PyTorch when supported; falls back to CPU automatically.

Choose the initial seed image for MFDeconv:
‚Ä¢ Robust Œº‚ÄìœÉ: running mean with sigma clipping (RAM-friendly, default)
‚Ä¢ Median: tiled median stack (more outlier-resistant; heavier I/O, esp. for XISF)
Lower = stronger masking near stars; 0 = hard mask, 0.2 = gentle.
Restore MFDeconv star mask + variance map tuning to the recommended defaults.
High/Low œÉ used by sigma-based rejection.
Std-devs from median; higher = more lenient.
Fraction trimmed on each end before averaging.
Pixels above this image quantile are treated as saturated and never replaced.

When checked, once calibration finishes the app will switch to Image Registration and run 'Register and Integrate Images' automatically.

CMOS users: Bias Subtraction is not needed.
Modern CMOS cameras use Correlated Double Sampling (CDS),
meaning bias is already subtracted at the sensor level.

For OSC dual-band data: SII/OIII ‚Üí R=SII, G=OIII; Ha/OIII ‚Üí R=Ha, G=OIII
Requires 'Enable Drizzle'. Maps R/G/B CFA samples directly into channels (no interpolation).
If checked, the best measured frame is accepted automatically.
Runs multi-frame deconvolution during integration. Turn off if testing.

Reconstruct on an r√ó super-res grid using SR PSFs.
Compute cost grows roughly ~ r^4. Drizzle usually provides better results.
If enabled, saves the seed and every iteration image into a subfolder next to the final output.

Œ∫ (kappa) limits how big each multiplicative update can be per iteration.
‚Ä¢ Œ∫ = 1.0 ‚Üí no change (1√ó); larger Œ∫ allows bigger step sizes.
‚Ä¢ Lower values = gentler, safer updates; higher values = faster but riskier.
Typical: 1.05‚Äì1.5 for conservative, ~2 for punchier updates.
‚ÄòLuma‚Äô deconvolves luminance only; ‚ÄòPerChannel‚Äô runs on RGB independently.

Huber Œ¥ sets the cutoff between ‚Äòquadratic‚Äô (treat as normal) and ‚Äòlinear‚Äô (treat as outlier) behavior.
‚Ä¢ |residual| ‚â§ Œ¥ ‚Üí quadratic (more aggressive corrections)
‚Ä¢ |residual| > Œ¥ ‚Üí linear (gentler, more robust)
Negative values mean ‚Äòscale by RMS‚Äô: e.g., Œ¥ = -2 uses 2√óRMS.
Smaller |Œ¥| (closer to 0) ‚Üí more pixels counted as outliers ‚Üí more conservative.
Examples: Œ∫=1.1 & Œ¥=-0.7 = gentle; Œ∫=2 & Œ¥=-2 = more aggressive.
Skip registration/alignment and use Maximum-Intensity projection for star trails
Downloads PyTorch with the right backend (CUDA/MPS/CPU). One-time per machine.

This app is running on Python {0}.{1}. GPU acceleration requires Python 3.10, 3.11, or 3.12.

macOS tip (Apple Silicon):
 ‚Ä¢ Install Python 3.12:  brew install python@3.12
 ‚Ä¢ Then relaunch the app so it can create its runtime with 3.12.

Windows tip:
 ‚Ä¢ Install Python 3.12/3.11/3.10 (x64) from python.org
 ‚Ä¢ Then relaunch the app.

Linux tip:
 ‚Ä¢ Install python3.12 or 3.11 via your package manager
 ‚Ä¢ Then relaunch the app.
